content: Which businesses will be damaged by self-driving cars, and which will benefit? Alan Jones Blocked Unblock Follow Following Apr 26 Photo by Alessio Lin on  Unsplash Autonomous vehicles will disrupt the transport sector and will have a significant knock on effect on related industries, too. So which businesses will be the winners and which the losers? The precise impact of the driver-less car will depend on which model of ownership is adopted. Will we continue to own private cars, or, as they become cheaper, will we rely on autonomous ride-hailing services from the likes of Uber and Lyft ? Because, if those services are cheap enough — and the cost savings of having no driver and the adoption of electric vehicles could mean that they are — private ownership could become a thing of the past. Also, fewer private cars will mean considerably fewer cars altogether. private cars spend most of their time at a standstill The reason is fairly clear: private cars spend most of their time at a standstill, parked in the road or in a garage. Whereas, companies running autonomous vehicles will make sure that their assets are sweated as much as possible. The result? All those cars that are currently sitting around doing nothing won’t be needed. This will have a large impact on industry as well as society. But which companies will be most affected? Transportation and Tech companies, for sure, but there are others that will be impacted both positively and negatively. Insurance, for example, motor manufacturing, healthcare… We’ll take look at some. Transportation This broadly breaks down into two sectors, passenger transport and freight. Both will undergo significant changes. Passengers Taxi companies, in cities at least, will use self-driving cars. And they are likely to be be app-driven organisations like Uber or Lyft whose biggest cost, at the moment, is drivers. So, adopting self-driving cars will reduce costs for the company and make them more profitable. companies will diversify into… scooters or bicycles It is also likely that these companies will diversify into other methods of transport: scooters or bicycles could be (and are being) deployed in town centres for short journeys and could be run from the same software platform as the self-driving cars generating more revenue for the companies. Taxi firms that embrace the new technologies could thrive but, except for niche markets, those that do not will whither away. Freight Navigating major routes across countries is easier than driving through towns. There are fewer hazards (like pedestrians and cyclists) so long-distance autonomous trucks should have an easier job than an urban taxi. But another approach is ‘platooning’ where a truck driven by a human leads, and controls, a bunch of other driverless trucks follow it. It’s a little like a road going freight train, except that the trucks are connected to each other electronically rather than physically. Whether completely autonomous, or platooned, freight transport will be much more efficient because fewer drivers will be able to move more freight. Autonomous trucks will be more efficient, too, they will not brake too hard or accelerate too quickly and thus save energy. So it seems likely that both freight and passenger transportation will become cheaper and more profitable. The real losers will, of course, be the drivers. Manufacturing a huge effect on manufacturing and… GDP If autonomous vehicles signal the end of the private car, then far fewer cars will be needed. This could have a huge effect on manufacturing and the GDP of countries where motor manufacturing is a significant part of the economy. Fewer cars mean fewer, or smaller manufacturers. In contrast, companies that provide high-tech components such as sensors and Lidar, could do very well. Also, the software companies that develop the AI that AVs will depend on should prosper. There may one challenge to these high-tech companies. As they become more sophisticated, AVs will communicate with each other in order to coordinate their movements and warn each other of hazards or delays. This means that they will have to be compatible. The communication protocols that they use will need to be standardised and this could lead to a single AI system being used in the majority of cars. We could end up with a situation much like we have with computer operating systems or smartphones, where one manufacturer dominates the market (i.e. Microsoft with Windows and Google with Android). Fine for the winner but not so great for other smaller competitors. Other industries Other businesses will also be effected. Fewer private cars will mean less oil will be used and fewer customers for the insurance companies. And, since many traffic accidents are caused by human error, there will be fewer accidents to pay out for — this should, theoretically, reduce the cost of insurance. Fewer accidents will mean fewer injuries. Will that have any impact on hospital accident and emergency departments? One could hope that it might. Oil prices will fall Fewer cars will also mean less oil will be consumed, in fact, it is likely that urban transport will be entirely electric, reducing pollution in city centres and further reducing the demand for oil. Oil prices will fall and, in consequence, the more expensive methods of oil extraction may well become uneconomic. There will doubtless be other effects that will be felt should AVs become common and private car ownership becomes rarer. Some businesses will reap the rewards, others may have to diversify and some will no doubt fail. Alan Jones : Web | Twitter :@MrAlanJones| Blogger
title_html: Which businesses will be damaged by self-driving cars, and which will benefit?
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Predict
Sign inGet started

Which businesses will be damaged by self-driving cars, and which will benefit?

Alan Jones
Apr 26

Autonomous vehicles will disrupt the transport sector and will have a significant knock on effect on related industries, too.

So which businesses will be the winners and which the losers?

The precise impact of the driver-less car will depend on which model of ownership is adopted.

Will we continue to own private cars, or, as they become cheaper, will we rely on autonomous ride-hailing services from the likes of Uber and Lyft?

Because, if those services are cheap enough — and the cost savings of having no driver and the adoption of electric vehicles could mean that they are — private ownership could become a thing of the past.

Also, fewer private cars will mean considerably fewer cars altogether.

private cars spend most of their time at a standstill

The reason is fairly clear: private cars spend most of their time at a standstill, parked in the road or in a garage. Whereas, companies running autonomous vehicles will make sure that their assets are sweated as much as possible. The result? All those cars that are currently sitting around doing nothing won’t be needed.

This will have a large impact on industry as well as society. But which companies will be most affected?

Transportation and Tech companies, for sure, but there are others that will be impacted both positively and negatively. Insurance, for example, motor manufacturing, healthcare…

We’ll take look at some.

Transportation

This broadly breaks down into two sectors, passenger transport and freight. Both will undergo significant changes.

Passengers

Taxi companies, in cities at least, will use self-driving cars. And they are likely to be be app-driven organisations like Uber or Lyft whose biggest cost, at the moment, is drivers.

So, adopting self-driving cars will reduce costs for the company and make them more profitable.

companies will diversify into… scooters or bicycles

It is also likely that these companies will diversify into other methods of transport: scooters or bicycles could be (and are being) deployed in town centres for short journeys and could be run from the same software platform as the self-driving cars generating more revenue for the companies.

Taxi firms that embrace the new technologies could thrive but, except for niche markets, those that do not will whither away.

Freight

Navigating major routes across countries is easier than driving through towns. There are fewer hazards (like pedestrians and cyclists) so long-distance autonomous trucks should have an easier job than an urban taxi.

But another approach is ‘platooning’ where a truck driven by a human leads, and controls, a bunch of other driverless trucks follow it. It’s a little like a road going freight train, except that the trucks are connected to each other electronically rather than physically.

Whether completely autonomous, or platooned, freight transport will be much more efficient because fewer drivers will be able to move more freight. Autonomous trucks will be more efficient, too, they will not brake too hard or accelerate too quickly and thus save energy.

So it seems likely that both freight and passenger transportation will become cheaper and more profitable.

The real losers will, of course, be the drivers.

Manufacturing

a huge effect on manufacturing and… GDP

If autonomous vehicles signal the end of the private car, then far fewer cars will be needed. This could have a huge effect on manufacturing and the GDP of countries where motor manufacturing is a significant part of the economy.

Fewer cars mean fewer, or smaller manufacturers.

In contrast, companies that provide high-tech components such as sensors and Lidar, could do very well. Also, the software companies that develop the AI that AVs will depend on should prosper.

There may one challenge to these high-tech companies. As they become more sophisticated, AVs will communicate with each other in order to coordinate their movements and warn each other of hazards or delays. This means that they will have to be compatible. The communication protocols that they use will need to be standardised and this could lead to a single AI system being used in the majority of cars.

We could end up with a situation much like we have with computer operating systems or smartphones, where one manufacturer dominates the market (i.e. Microsoft with Windows and Google with Android). Fine for the winner but not so great for other smaller competitors.

Other industries

Other businesses will also be effected. Fewer private cars will mean less oil will be used and fewer customers for the insurance companies.

And, since many traffic accidents are caused by human error, there will be fewer accidents to pay out for — this should, theoretically, reduce the cost of insurance.

Fewer accidents will mean fewer injuries. Will that have any impact on hospital accident and emergency departments? One could hope that it might.

Oil prices will fall

Fewer cars will also mean less oil will be consumed, in fact, it is likely that urban transport will be entirely electric, reducing pollution in city centres and further reducing the demand for oil. Oil prices will fall and, in consequence, the more expensive methods of oil extraction may well become uneconomic.

There will doubtless be other effects that will be felt should AVs become common and private car ownership becomes rarer. Some businesses will reap the rewards, others may have to diversify and some will no doubt fail.

Alan Jones : Web|Twitter:@MrAlanJones|Blogger

  • Self Driving Cars
  • Business
  • Future Technology
  • Autonomous Vehicles
  • Transport

  • Alan Jones

    An ex-university professor and software engineer, I write about AI, programming and technology. Twitter:@MrAlanJones Web:https://alanjones.pythonanywhere.com

title: Which businesses will be damaged by self-driving cars, and which will benefit?
content_html:
Which businesses will be damaged by self-driving cars, and which will benefit?

Alan Jones
Apr 26

Autonomous vehicles will disrupt the transport sector and will have a significant knock on effect on related industries, too.

So which businesses will be the winners and which the losers?

The precise impact of the driver-less car will depend on which model of ownership is adopted.

Will we continue to own private cars, or, as they become cheaper, will we rely on autonomous ride-hailing services from the likes of Uber and Lyft?

Because, if those services are cheap enough — and the cost savings of having no driver and the adoption of electric vehicles could mean that they are — private ownership could become a thing of the past.

Also, fewer private cars will mean considerably fewer cars altogether.

private cars spend most of their time at a standstill

The reason is fairly clear: private cars spend most of their time at a standstill, parked in the road or in a garage. Whereas, companies running autonomous vehicles will make sure that their assets are sweated as much as possible. The result? All those cars that are currently sitting around doing nothing won’t be needed.

This will have a large impact on industry as well as society. But which companies will be most affected?

Transportation and Tech companies, for sure, but there are others that will be impacted both positively and negatively. Insurance, for example, motor manufacturing, healthcare…

This broadly breaks down into two sectors, passenger transport and freight. Both will undergo significant changes.

Passengers

Taxi companies, in cities at least, will use self-driving cars. And they are likely to be be app-driven organisations like Uber or Lyft whose biggest cost, at the moment, is drivers.

So, adopting self-driving cars will reduce costs for the company and make them more profitable.

companies will diversify into… scooters or bicycles

It is also likely that these companies will diversify into other methods of transport: scooters or bicycles could be (and are being) deployed in town centres for short journeys and could be run from the same software platform as the self-driving cars generating more revenue for the companies.

Taxi firms that embrace the new technologies could thrive but, except for niche markets, those that do not will whither away.

Navigating major routes across countries is easier than driving through towns. There are fewer hazards (like pedestrians and cyclists) so long-distance autonomous trucks should have an easier job than an urban taxi.

But another approach is ‘platooning’ where a truck driven by a human leads, and controls, a bunch of other driverless trucks follow it. It’s a little like a road going freight train, except that the trucks are connected to each other electronically rather than physically.

Whether completely autonomous, or platooned, freight transport will be much more efficient because fewer drivers will be able to move more freight. Autonomous trucks will be more efficient, too, they will not brake too hard or accelerate too quickly and thus save energy.

So it seems likely that both freight and passenger transportation will become cheaper and more profitable.

The real losers will, of course, be the drivers.

a huge effect on manufacturing and… GDP

If autonomous vehicles signal the end of the private car, then far fewer cars will be needed. This could have a huge effect on manufacturing and the GDP of countries where motor manufacturing is a significant part of the economy.

Fewer cars mean fewer, or smaller manufacturers.

In contrast, companies that provide high-tech components such as sensors and Lidar, could do very well. Also, the software companies that develop the AI that AVs will depend on should prosper.

There may one challenge to these high-tech companies. As they become more sophisticated, AVs will communicate with each other in order to coordinate their movements and warn each other of hazards or delays. This means that they will have to be compatible. The communication protocols that they use will need to be standardised and this could lead to a single AI system being used in the majority of cars.

We could end up with a situation much like we have with computer operating systems or smartphones, where one manufacturer dominates the market (i.e. Microsoft with Windows and Google with Android). Fine for the winner but not so great for other smaller competitors.

Other industries

Other businesses will also be effected. Fewer private cars will mean less oil will be used and fewer customers for the insurance companies.

And, since many traffic accidents are caused by human error, there will be fewer accidents to pay out for — this should, theoretically, reduce the cost of insurance.

Fewer accidents will mean fewer injuries. Will that have any impact on hospital accident and emergency departments? One could hope that it might.

Oil prices will fall

Fewer cars will also mean less oil will be consumed, in fact, it is likely that urban transport will be entirely electric, reducing pollution in city centres and further reducing the demand for oil. Oil prices will fall and, in consequence, the more expensive methods of oil extraction may well become uneconomic.

There will doubtless be other effects that will be felt should AVs become common and private car ownership becomes rarer. Some businesses will reap the rewards, others may have to diversify and some will no doubt fail.

Alan Jones : Web|Twitter:@MrAlanJones|Blogger
